intro: Ulmus glabra subsp. scabra, commonly known as the scabrous elm, is a subspecies of the European elm characterized by its rough, fissured bark. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters, featuring a broad, spreading crown. The leaves are ovate to elliptic, with serrated margins and a matte green upper surface. It prefers moist, well-drained soils and is often found in riparian zones or along riverbanks. The subspecies is noted for its resilience to urban conditions and its role in supporting local biodiversity.
